newsitem.title: USA: Merrill sees 'no liability' in S'tomo loss.
newsitem.headline: Merrill sees 'no liability' in S'tomo loss.

text.p: Merrill Lynch said it acted in good faith with Sumitomo Corp and sees no liability from the copper scandal.

"We conducted all of our business with Sumitomo in good faith, and in an entirely proper manner," said Merrill Lynch spokesman James Wiggins. "In any event, we do not believe we would have any liability in connection with transactions conducted with them."
Merrill has said all its trades with Sumitomo were authorized at senior levels.
Earlier Tuesday, Sumitomo's disgraced former head copper trader Yasuo Hamanaka was arrested for forgery after his Tokyo home was raided by prosecutors.
Tokyo District Prosecutor's Office said he was under suspicion of forging the signature of a Sumitomo board member on two letters in 1994.
The letters said he had the authority to enter into certain metal transactions and to designate recipients of funds deposited with the firms in the Merrill Lynch group.
Naoki Kuroda, a managing director at Sumitomo, said on Tuesday that the company had found no evidence that would lead it to file complaints against foreign metals brokers that dealt with Hamanaka.
